content:
This is just unguessable in reverse mode !
I've removed it.

Most languages that I know have built-in Integer<-->String base conversion function. A simple call to such a function will finish this crash. In this sense it is too straight-forward and no-brainer type.

I edited the puzzle.
Password length is now always a multiple of 4, so it include leading zeros when needed.
Constraint is adjusted to actually match test cases.
I like the puzzle and i do not think it is too simple. Maybe it would be a bit better, especially for reverse, if the length would always be a multiple of 4.

I like this (and the other) puzzle. I think the difficulty is perfect.

However, I am missing details about the encoding scheme since  you just say "a group of similar binary-to-text encoding schemes".  I'd have expected strings matching `([0-3]{4})*`, i.e. strings consisting of multiples of 4 consecutive base-4 digits. However, your examples show an uneven amount of digits:
"*" -> "222".
Shouldn't this be "0222" since "*" is "00101010" in ASCII?

Also, I'd vote against  the reverse mode for this puzzle.

Really ?! base 4 decoding ....

as for https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/1510cdd8ecc1d199fc2971f8befd08b39e2a

too simple ... just need split, base conversion and ord
password length never reach 128 in your tests ....

i say no too

Cf https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/1510cdd8ecc1d199fc2971f8befd08b39e2a

--

I don't feel that way. Yes. it is simple, but some Clash of Code are so much easier. And that's good. CoC should stay an arcade game where the problem is not "Can I finish it", but more "How fast can I finish it".

For the length constraint, I saw a lot of CoC where constraints was a very exaggerated upperbound, so I choosed to do the same. I'm not sure if it is a good practice, I'm ready to change it. I Just need a confirmation.
